pros: First class colleagues Interesting work Great environment
cons: Pay could be better but I'm clutching straws

job_title: Accommodation Operations Assistant in Stirling, Scotland
pros: Beautiful campus in leafy town. Days off.
cons: Frontline Accomadation staff from a variety of previously high level backgrounds are routinely ignored and disrespected by the senior management team who are preoccupied with chasing their next promotion within the department rather than managing effectively, short term bandaid solutions are crippling the accomadation buildings. If it was a school inspection the team would be removed and the school put in special measures. Management staff are obsessed with titles and embellishing their email signatures. On the whole their is a deficit of experience within the management team and schoolboy errors are routinely made that could be avoided if they opted for a positive and consultative approach rather than ramming things through that were tried and failed years previously. Within the team it has been known that frontline accomadation staff are turning to food banks to feed themselves due to the low rates of depressed pay. This at a time when the management team has grown 50% in size. Stacking shelves in Tesco or washing cars pays the same these days without the grief and victimisation experienced here. The atmosphere is unhealthy and there is a lot of favourites. A large proportion of staff are related to each other like a family firm with all the issues that entails. Nobody competent would ever be promoted that would embarrass the Head, it’s all micromanaged badly with no decisions approved until the dear leader rubber stamps them. This is to the detriment of the buildings which have been starved of investment in recent times, managers and Directors don’t notice as they are pretty much welded to there office chairs.

pros: Great working here. Good staff and managing committee
cons: Training is not efficient. I had to figure out lot of things on my own.

pros: Location Campus Teaching facilities Sports centre
cons: Very poor leadership Student recruitment has been ignored under current vc - very poor culture Poor progression Teaching staff have limited progression and its far harder to get promotion than research and teaching staff High turnover of staff - now struggling to recruit good staff from other universities or into the sector

job_title: Professional Services Manager in Stirling, Scotland
pros:
Working from home available a few days a week
Opportunities for promotion or moves into other areas available due to high staff turnover
Focus on the brand and external perceptions
Campus grounds nice in summer
Good holiday allocation as part of contract
cons:
Very high staff turnover 
Lack of professional staff development 
Clusters of male management groups, lack of diversity 
Location of campus and transport links difficult travelling from Edinburgh and Glasgow, time consuming and costly
Toxic culture - negative practices 
Staffing resources are the bare minimum
Focus on income generating areas - student recruitment and research
Tired main teaching buildings, facilities and equipment
Old fashioned working practices

pros: There are friendly colleagues below management

review_title: Lack of strategy and poor leadership
pros: Lovely campus, beautiful outdoors, good gym facilities.
cons: The Peter Principle is strongly evidenced here through poor leadership, lack of managerial knowledge or experience, and a complete absence of capacity to develop any strategy or even agree strategic objectives. Managers tell lies, are verbally abusive, manipulative and often bully junior staff, creating a toxic work culture. There is no willingness to listen to staff feedback, even that provided through official channels. I have never worked in such a toxic environment before, and hope I never have to again.

pros: Good hourly pay, very flexible since you can choose which tours and days you take on or sign up for, great communication, great for your CV.

pros: 43 days of holidays, nice location, some friendly staff
cons: Where do i begin? Very manual tasks with very limiting accounting package.  several systems that do mot talk to each other. Manual performance of tasks not secured by any controls. Shocking lack of knowledge retention. Long serving employees resign and take away all their knowledge with them. No on-boarding or knowledge transfer exist. Lack of order, non existing investment in staff, workload is ever increasing with no recognition. Target driven. Making it Happen achievement at any cost. No proper support to service areas. Gazillions of politics. A rotten and toxic environment to work in. Feels like you are stuck in 1990.  Blame culture very visible. staff turnover is huge. Loyalty is not rewarded. Leadership Is flawed. Bad dream. Glad my experience is now over.
